content.title: Bone Marrow Biopsy
content.summary: Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy is an essential diagnostic procedure in hematology, providing direct assessment of marrow cellularity, morphology, and architecture for diagnosis and staging of hematologic malignancies, evaluation of cytopenias, and monitoring treatment response.
key_points: Combines aspiration (liquid sample for morphology, flow cytometry, cytogenetics) and core biopsy (architecture, cellularity)
Posterior superior iliac crest is preferred site; anterior iliac crest or sternum as alternatives
Indications include unexplained cytopenias, suspected hematologic malignancy, staging, and treatment response assessment
Aspirate provides cells for morphology, flow cytometry, cytogenetics, and molecular testing
Core biopsy allows assessment of cellularity, fibrosis, architecture, and immunohistochemistry
Complications are rare (<1%) but include bleeding, infection, and needle fracture
content.statement: Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy is a minimally invasive procedure obtaining liquid marrow aspirate and a solid core biopsy specimen from the posterior iliac crest, providing essential diagnostic information including marrow cellularity, cell morphology, architecture, and material for ancillary testing (flow cytometry, cytogenetics, molecular studies) in the evaluation of hematologic disorders.

explanation.intuition: The bone marrow is the factory for blood cells. When blood counts are abnormal or malignancy is suspected, directly examining the marrow provides information that peripheral blood cannot - including cellularity, maturation patterns, abnormal cell populations, and architectural changes like fibrosis.
explanation.key_insight: Aspiration and biopsy are complementary: the aspirate gives individual cells for detailed morphology and flow cytometry, while the core biopsy shows the big picture - overall cellularity, architecture, and patterns of involvement that can be missed in liquid samples, especially in fibrotic marrows where aspiration may yield a 'dry tap.'
explanation.technical_details: Procedure uses local anesthesia (lidocaine) ± conscious sedation. Jamshidi needle (11-gauge) penetrates cortical bone; aspirate obtained first (1-2 mL for morphology; additional for studies). Core biopsy follows, obtaining 1.5-2 cm cylinder of trabecular bone. Aspirate smears prepared immediately; core fixed in formalin or B5 for histologic processing. Touch imprints from core provide morphology when aspirate is inadequate.

definitions_glossary.bone_marrow_aspiration: Procedure obtaining liquid marrow sample using needle and syringe for morphologic examination and ancillary studies
definitions_glossary.bone_marrow_biopsy: Procedure obtaining solid core of trabecular bone and marrow for histologic examination of architecture and cellularity
definitions_glossary.posterior_iliac_crest: Preferred site for bone marrow procedure; accessible, safe, and provides adequate sample
definitions_glossary.jamshidi_needle: Standard 11-gauge needle designed for bone marrow aspiration and core biopsy
definitions_glossary.cellularity: Percentage of marrow space occupied by hematopoietic cells versus fat; normally decreases with age
definitions_glossary.dry_tap: Failure to obtain liquid aspirate; occurs with fibrosis, hypercellularity, or poor technique; core biopsy essential
definitions_glossary.touch_imprint: Cytologic preparation made by touching core biopsy to slide; provides morphology when aspirate unavailable
definitions_glossary.flow_cytometry: Immunophenotyping technique identifying cell surface markers; requires fresh aspirate sample
definitions_glossary.cytogenetics: Chromosome analysis requiring viable dividing cells from fresh aspirate
definitions_glossary.fish: Fluorescence in situ hybridization detecting specific genetic abnormalities on aspirate or biopsy
definitions_glossary.iron_stain: Perl's Prussian blue stain on aspirate assessing marrow iron stores and ring sideroblasts
definitions_glossary.reticulin_stain: Silver stain on core biopsy demonstrating fibrosis (myelofibrosis grading)

diagnostic.cytopenias: Unexplained anemia, neutropenia, or thrombocytopenia; pancytopenia evaluation
diagnostic.suspected_malignancy: Leukemia, lymphoma, myeloma, myelodysplastic syndrome, myeloproliferative neoplasms
diagnostic.fever_of_unknown_origin: Evaluate for infection (granulomas, organisms), malignancy, or hemophagocytic syndrome
diagnostic.splenomegaly: Evaluate for infiltrative disorders, storage diseases

staging.lymphoma: Marrow involvement affects stage (Stage IV Hodgkin, higher stage NHL)
staging.solid_tumors: Metastatic involvement assessment (neuroblastoma, breast, lung, prostate)
staging.plasma_cell_disorders: Quantify plasma cell percentage for myeloma diagnosis and response

monitoring.mrd_assessment: Minimal residual disease by flow or molecular methods

site_selection.posterior_iliac_crest: Preferred in adults and children >1 year; patient prone or lateral decubitus
site_selection.anterior_iliac_crest: Alternative when posterior inaccessible; patient supine
site_selection.sternum: Aspiration only; rarely used due to complication risk
site_selection.tibia: Used in infants <1 year when iliac crest too small

preparation.consent: Explain procedure, risks, and alternatives; document informed consent
preparation.medications: Review anticoagulants; may need to hold or bridge depending on urgency
preparation.sedation: Local anesthesia standard; conscious sedation for anxious patients or children

procedure_steps.positioning: Prone or lateral with adequate exposure of posterior iliac crest
procedure_steps.local_anesthesia: Lidocaine 1-2% infiltrated through skin, subcutaneous tissue, and periosteum
procedure_steps.aspiration: Insert needle to marrow cavity; attach syringe and aspirate 1-2 mL quickly (minimizes peripheral blood dilution)
procedure_steps.biopsy: Reposition needle slightly; advance with rotational pressure; obtain 1.5-2 cm core
procedure_steps.specimen_handling: Immediate smear preparation; anticoagulated tubes for flow/cytogenetics; formalin for core

aspirate.morphology: Wright-Giemsa stained smears for differential count, maturation, dysplasia
aspirate.iron_stain: Perl's Prussian blue on aspirate particles for iron stores and ring sideroblasts
aspirate.flow_cytometry: EDTA anticoagulated sample for immunophenotyping (leukemia, lymphoma)
aspirate.molecular: For PCR, NGS testing (fresh or frozen)

core_biopsy.fixation: Formalin or B5 (mercury-based, better morphology but toxic)
core_biopsy.processing: Decalcification (acid or EDTA), paraffin embedding, sectioning
core_biopsy.stains: H&E routine; reticulin for fibrosis; iron; special stains as indicated
core_biopsy.immunohistochemistry: CD markers, Ki-67, etc. on paraffin sections

cellularity_assessment.hypercellular: Increased cells; seen in malignancy, infection, hemolysis, myeloproliferative disorders
cellularity_assessment.hypocellular: Decreased cells; aplastic anemia, post-chemotherapy, aging

morphology_findings.maturation: Normal orderly maturation vs left shift, maturation arrest
morphology_findings.blasts: Immature cells; >20% diagnostic for acute leukemia (AML/ALL)
morphology_findings.infiltrates: Lymphoma, plasma cells, metastatic tumor, granulomas

special_findings.ring_sideroblasts: Iron in mitochondria around nucleus (MDS-RS, sideroblastic anemia)

common.pain: Most common; managed with local anesthesia and post-procedure analgesia
common.bleeding: Minor bleeding at site usual; significant hemorrhage rare (<0.1%)

rare_serious.hemorrhage: Risk increased with thrombocytopenia or anticoagulation; may need transfusion
rare_serious.needle_fracture: Rare; requires surgical removal if fragment retained
rare_serious.nerve_injury: Transient paresthesia occasionally; permanent injury extremely rare

skos.definition: A diagnostic procedure obtaining liquid marrow aspirate and solid core biopsy from the posterior iliac crest for morphologic, immunophenotypic, cytogenetic, and molecular evaluation of hematologic disorders.

icd10_pcs.display: Extraction of bone marrow from pelvic bone, open approach, diagnostic

learning_objectives: List indications for bone marrow aspiration and biopsy
Describe the technique for posterior iliac crest bone marrow procedure
Explain the complementary information from aspirate versus core biopsy
Identify specimens needed for various ancillary studies
Interpret basic findings including cellularity, blasts, and fibrosis
Recognize complications and contraindications of the procedure
clinical_pearls: A 'dry tap' (no aspirate obtained) suggests fibrosis or packed marrow - core biopsy becomes essential
First pull of aspirate should be small (1-2 mL) to minimize peripheral blood dilution
Touch imprints from core biopsy provide morphology when aspirate is inadequate
Cellularity roughly equals 100 minus patient age (guideline, not absolute)
Always send samples for all potentially needed studies - repeat procedures are patient burden
Platelet count >20,000/μL generally safe; below this, consider platelet transfusion before or after

board_yield.usmle_step1: Hematopoiesis sites, marrow anatomy, stem cell differentiation
board_yield.usmle_step2: Indications, basic interpretation, when to order bone marrow
board_yield.usmle_step3: Consent considerations, anticoagulation management, result interpretation
board_yield.abim_hematology: Detailed morphology, differential diagnosis, integration with flow/cytogenetics

common_misconceptions: Misconception: Aspiration and biopsy are redundant. Reality: They provide complementary information; both usually needed
Misconception: Low platelets are absolute contraindication. Reality: Relative; transfuse and proceed if clinically necessary
Misconception: Marrow exam can always diagnose the problem. Reality: Some disorders require correlation with blood, clinical, and other studies
